newsitem.title: USA: Fran strikes land with gusts over 120 mph.
newsitem.headline: Fran strikes land with gusts over 120 mph.

text.p: The eye of Hurricane Fran pushed ashore near Cape Fear, North Carolina, shortly after 8 p.m. (midnight GMT), weather forecasters said.
Wind gusts were clocked at more than 120 mph (193 kmh) as the storm hit land, according to local emergency officials in Wilmington.
Sustained winds of 75 mph (120 kmh) were recorded in Wilmington, about 40 miles (about 60 km) north of Cape Fear.
Christy Moore, a spokeswoman for the Brunswick County emergency operations centre, said the Cape Fear River was obscured by blowing rain and ocean spray.
"The winds are really picking up. We've had a couple of houses with trees on them," Moore told reporters.
Fran lifted shingles off roofs of buildings and tossed them into the Cape Fear River. Bright orange flashes lit up the sky in nearby Wilmington as electrical transformers exploded, officials said.
